Brotato is, without question, one of the most addictive arena survival shooters to come out in recent years. For the first dozen or so hours, the core loop is pure, frantic fun. Mowing down hundreds of aliens with six absurdly scaled weapons feels immensely satisfying, and the sheer variety of characters and weapon types promises a playground of build crafting and experimentation. The game starts strong, reeling you in with that sweet, chaotic dopamine rush. (Time Played: 30+ Hours)

My enthusiasm, however, hit a brick wall right around the Danger 5 difficulty. The game shifts from a playful sandbox to a brutally rigid challenge where the initial promise of variety completely evaporates. The freedom to experiment is swiftly replaced by the grim necessity of following the current meta. If you don't commit to a handful of hyper-optimized builds (like Engineer/Wrench or specific high-harvesting stat-checkers), you end up getting utterly wrecked. Many characters and weapons simply feel non-viable for top-level completion, making the game feel lacking in the variety it initially advertised.

The most potent source of frustration lies specifically in the boss encounters. They feel less like a true skill check on your dodging and more like a cruel, pass/fail test on your build's DPS. The bosses‚Äô movement, characterized by sudden, dramatic leaps, combined with the immediate threat of high-damage red circles that gimp you if you stand in it before they go off, creates a disproportionately punishing experience. It often feels cheap, demanding flawless execution while simultaneously requiring you to have scaled your damage stats to an insane degree just to burn them down before they overrun the screen. The end result is runs being repeatedly killed by a single, unforgiving two-boss wave, regardless of how cleverly or defensively you played the previous 19 waves.

Final Verdict: Brotato is an easy recommendation for anyone looking for a highly addictive, fast-paced rogue-lite to sink 10-20 hours into casually. It's a fantastic game for clearing the lower difficulty levels and enjoying the diverse cast. However, if you are seeking a diverse, high-difficulty challenge where a wide range of creative builds are viable, or if you plan to conquer Danger 5 with every potato, prepare for genuine frustration. The late-game forces a stale, meta-driven grind that tarnishes the game's otherwise brilliant foundation.
pretty awesome game! singleplayer and couch coop are both extreme fun!
Good game to kick back and relax to after a long day at work

Brotato is an excellent addition to the roguelite auto-shooter genre. The sheer variety of characters, items, and synergies allows for an incredible number of distinct builds, ranging from absurdly powerful to hilariously chaotic. Every run feels different, and the unlock progression keeps you coming back for ‚Äújust one more wave.‚Äù
The base difficulty is genuinely challenging and rewarding, but if you ever want to dial it back (or crank it up even further), the modding support is outstanding and seamlessly integrated.
My only real complaint is the arena size. Compared to similar titles like Vampire Survivors, the play area feels noticeably more confined, which can make certain builds (especially melee or high-mobility ones) feel a bit cramped.
Aside from that minor gripe, Brotato is polished, addictive, and packed with replay value. Easily worth full price, and an absolute steal on sale.
9.5/10 ‚Äì Highly Recommended

Ahh, another roguelike. Made by Blobfish studios and being continued by Evil Empire. The same studio that mad Dead Cells DLC and The Rogue Prince of Persia. It is a game where you play as a potato and maybe with your Brotato's. You must fight the aliens from invading your planet. What do you do? You try to survive a minute in a wave of aliens, while collecting materials to buy upgrades and weapons. The waves getting progressively harder, with different aliens, and more of them. I could go on and on about the achievements and unlockables, but just know that there is a lot. You must survive 20 waves, wave 20 being a boss fight. You could end it at wave 20, or go endless. Each time you complete a wave difficulty, you unlock the next. There is also a TON of steam workshop items, cheats, funny, and just fun. I know Evil Empire is gonna add a lot more stuff to the game, and I will update my review when that happens. For now, worth the 5 bucks.

Brotato is an absolute blast. I went in expecting a simple little arena shooter to kill some time, and it quickly became one of my go-to "just one more run" games. The gameplay loop is fast, chaotic, and super satisfying‚Äîexactly the kind of fun that hooks you without feeling overwhelming.

What I love most is how easy it is to pick up. You can jump into a run within seconds, but there‚Äôs an impressive amount of depth once you start combining weapons, items, and character abilities. Every run feels different, and even the failures are fun because you immediately see what you want to try next.

The humor and style are great too. The little potato characters are surprisingly charming, and the variety of builds makes experimenting genuinely enjoyable. Plus, the game runs smoothly, loads instantly, and never gets in the way of the action.

If you like roguelikes, horde shooters, or just want something fast and ridiculously fun, Brotato is absolutely worth it. It‚Äôs one of those games that feels good from the first minute and keeps getting better the more you play.

Brotato: Finally, a game for the rest of us! 

I used to judge those people with thousands of hours in games, you know, the ones whose skin hasn't seen sunlight since dial-up was a thing. "Get a life!" I'd scoff, adjusting my perfectly ironed shirt before heading to my incredibly fulfilling job, where I'm a respected leader of a small, but vital, team. I'd then spend my evenings engaging in meaningful conversations with real humans, or perhaps mastering a complex new recipe.

But then... Brotato.

Now, my colleagues wonder why I'm "too busy" to join the lunch team-building exercises. My carefully cultivated social life has been replaced by an intense, unspoken rivalry with my own past high scores. I haven't seen a full night's sleep in weeks, fueled only by the primal urge to get that one last potato upgrade. My perfectly ironed shirts are now... optional.

This game is a deceptively simple, time-devouring vortex. It is my life now. And honestly? It's pretty good. I mean, who needs a 'life' when you can be a potato with 6 arms wielding rocket launchers? Definitely not me, apparently.

10/10 - Would neglect all responsibilities again.
Great game, with a ton of replay value. ~20 minute sessions per run, so a nice way to take a break in the day.

Definitely my least favorite rogue-like that I've played. Half the time I die is because my mouse cursor leaves the screen while moving. I like playing mouse-only controls because WASD was super janky. I'd just stand still randomly, and my character wouldn't always move in a diagonal pattern. If that's by design, it's bad design. Otherwise, it's bad coding. I'm not looking for a game like this to play with a controller, so that's out of the question. Mouse-only controls are super convenient and preferred. However, not being able to boost the size of the cursor or even highlight it makes it super hard to see when thousands of enemies are on the screen or it just blends in with default debris on the ground. It's really not a fun way to lose because you can't find the cursor. Especially not fun because it's on another screen despite being in full screen. This is the only game I've played where the mouse leaves the screen during active play regardless of being in Windowed or Fullscreen. No other game, rogue-lite/like or otherwise, does this unless I'm playing in Borderless Windowed AND I'm actively paused. Super bad game design. The only thing that keeps me attempting runs is the accessibility option to retry failed waves. I beat Difficulty 5 with the base character before turning this on. That said, if I didn't turn it on, I wouldn't be completing any runs because I'm dying to reasons out of my control. It shouldn't be this hard to actually be able to play the game. But then when you're playing the game, the balancing isn't fun. Builds are rarely fun even if I get something that feels overpowered. In other rogues, this type of build would just feel average. Other rogues I play also don't have 50 different stats to track to know if the item you're buying is going to make or break your build. That might be fun for some people, but there's a problem when the quantity of stats gets too high. Additionally, there are weapon types that unlock bonuses for having multiple of that weapon type equipped. Cool in concept, poor in execution like most things in this game. Tell me why the shears/trimmers or whatever are not a tool? It's literally a tool. It's only classified as support. Hammer, too. It's a tool. If you're going to make unique categories, make them make sense. That's something small to nitpick, but there isn't anything positive to say about this game. The number of characters is too high. The second zone (The Abyss) really doesn't feel different at all from the first. Every round is the same unless you play a character that has a debilitating ability like One-Armed (by the way, this one has been horrible. Literally pure RNG to get a run going. No way to adapt the run unlike other builds). The game is just poorly optimized in terms of mechanics and builds. There is never a reason for me to build anything other than a ranged build. I'll get the same things over and over just with a different potato. Again, if you like this game, power to you. But this is not for me at all. It's quite terrible. I'll keep trying it while I find another rogue to latch onto. But I do not see this review changing. It feels so uncomfortable to play with the janky mouse controls that leave the screen.

edit: Upon further investigation this is only obvious if there are more than 2 players, unless you can tell when something's off-center. Because it is. All of the UI elements are off-center. The re-roll button in the level up screen for example goes below the screen because in all of the menus between waves the entire interactive area is off-center diagonally.

Also I am nitpicking, but this is actually a decent game and probably still worth the price. I just don't like it when devs break something they change when it didn't need to be changed in the first place.

Idk holodive better, every match is just pure rng based and u get nothing for completing or winning or whatever. Just a infinite simulator that's a compelte reset per run till u die.

Fix multiplayer online per 2 per and i might actually rate it good.

I understand I am absolutely against the grain with this one. To give props where they are due this is a great survivor-like and fills the niche for many craving more with a satisfying build system. Personally however I found everything to simply feel very same-y and doesn't not offer anything unique that I cannot receive in other games that I enjoy more. I would absolutely recommend trying the game if it is interesting to you, but know there is minimal change to the formula nor variances without the DLC.

Im in the middle of playing, and i finished a round choose my upgrades and the whole game crashes, i open back up the game, click resume, finish same round, choose upgrades, after that, the game crashes AGAIN. And it goes on and on and on and on. Someone help me figure this out
was fun. played alot.  uninstalled.  reinstalled.  saves are gone.  not worth playing again from the start.

Definitely my least favorite rogue-like that I've played. Half the time I die is because my mouse cursor leaves the screen while moving. I like playing mouse-only controls because WASD was super janky. I'd just stand still randomly, and my character wouldn't always move in a diagonal pattern. If that's by design, it's bad design. Otherwise, it's bad coding. I'm not looking for a game like this to play with a controller, so that's out of the question. Mouse-only controls are super convenient and preferred. However, not being able to boost the size of the cursor or even highlight it makes it super hard to see when thousands of enemies are on the screen or it just blends in with default debris on the ground. It's really not a fun way to lose because you can't find the cursor. Especially not fun because it's on another screen despite being in full screen. This is the only game I've played where the mouse leaves the screen during active play regardless of being in Windowed or Fullscreen. No other game, rogue-lite/like or otherwise, does this unless I'm playing in Borderless Windowed AND I'm actively paused. Super bad game design. The only thing that keeps me attempting runs is the accessibility option to retry failed waves. I beat Difficulty 5 with the base character before turning this on. That said, if I didn't turn it on, I wouldn't be completing any runs because I'm dying to reasons out of my control. It shouldn't be this hard to actually be able to play the game. But then when you're playing the game, the balancing isn't fun. Builds are rarely fun even if I get something that feels overpowered. In other rogues, this type of build would just feel average. Other rogues I play also don't have 50 different stats to track to know if the item you're buying is going to make or break your build. That might be fun for some people, but there's a problem when the quantity of stats gets too high. Additionally, there are weapon types that unlock bonuses for having multiple of that weapon type equipped. Cool in concept, poor in execution like most things in this game. Tell me why the shears/trimmers or whatever are not a tool? It's literally a tool. It's only classified as support. Hammer, too. It's a tool. If you're going to make unique categories, make them make sense. That's something small to nitpick, but there isn't anything positive to say about this game. The number of characters is too high. The second zone (The Abyss) really doesn't feel different at all from the first. Every round is the same unless you play a character that has a debilitating ability like One-Armed (by the way, this one has been horrible. Literally pure RNG to get a run going. No way to adapt the run unlike other builds). The game is just poorly optimized in terms of mechanics and builds. There is never a reason for me to build anything other than a ranged build. I'll get the same things over and over just with a different potato. Again, if you like this game, power to you. But this is not for me at all. It's quite terrible. I'll keep trying it while I find another rogue to latch onto. But I do not see this review changing. It feels so uncomfortable to play with the janky mouse controls that leave the screen.

This game used to be wonderful to play and have fun with, however due to the most recent update this game as been rendered unplayable due to a extremely poorly optimised enemy causing a crash every time I boot it up
This game is for people with brain damage. ASD. Who decided it's gonna be fun to have game loop concept. Imagine playing game for the sake of playing. Monotonous brainf*ck.
I do like this game but I've never play one single run coop that didn't end with a dc. Game has been out too long to have such a critical issue. DO NOT PLAY THIS GAME
Play it casually, don't get attached to your progress. A random update may delete it.
wtf is happening i cant paly my computer crashes everytime i openit
Games like vampire survivors aren't really for me, but if you like those, go ahead!

Prior to the buyout, I would have recommended it, post buyout, it looks like 3 dev teams made it without working together at all, it's an eye bleach combination of aesthetics.  Looks horrid, also I lost a LOT of progress and was reset to 0 wins.
Game is trash. No cool map to walk around just a small spawning trash simulator. Learn to make a good walkable map.
After 67 hours in this time waster, the game reset my progress and I'm back at square 1. What a collossal waste.
You need to FIX how when you are over with the mission and you are looking at your items it jumps around sometimes instead of going to the next item. FIX IT!

mid and music too repetitive

first few hours was fun, but the scaling on builds and upgrades is really wonky.  never really feels like you can build an ultra fun build.  almost feels like upgrades fall off in magnitude the bigger the number.

In spite of playing many hours in the genre I've never really been able to engage with this game, the loop just doesn't satisfy, the music is neither hype or chill just there, for me, it's art is okay but doesn't click any taste of mine, the weapon variety....well there's a lot but they all seem to fall into melee or range, in the sense all in a group feels the same 

Wish I could recommend. Or maybe just give a neutral, it's such a cheap product I guess if your inclined to these types of games then it is worth giving a go.
Its fun, but way too many enemies spawn and its way too easy in the early waves, and way too difficult in the later waves.
literally cant be played after the new update that ruined saves. me and hundreds of others are having the same issue. i will NOT fix the review until they make the game playable!!!!

they vibe coded the update or something cause the game is actually visually ass now, please go back

The re-roll button in the level up screen for example goes below the screen because in all of the menus between waves the entire interactive area is off-center diagonally.

Also I am nitpicking, but this is actually a decent game and probably still worth the price. I just don't like it when devs break something they change when it didn't need to be changed in the first place.
